attributes.title: Examining Screen Time & Mental Health in Emerging Adults

q1.value: Technology Use & Mental Health in Canadian Youth: An Examination of Nationally Representative Data

q3.value: There is a lack of consistent research supporting the affects of technology use on mental health. The purpose of this study is to examine the nature of the relationship between increasingly high levels of screen time on the mental health of Canadian youth. Furthermore, evidence to support either the Goldilocks hypothesis or exposure-response hypothesis will be concluded. Specifically, an examination between the technology usage and mental health while moderating for various demographic factors like age, sex, and socioeconomic status will be conducted

q4.value:
It is hypothesized that the results will support an exposure-response hypothesis. Therefore, mental health will peak at light use of digital media followed by a steady decrease in overall mental health as digital media usage increases.
As a result of the declining trend of technology usage as age increases, it is hypothesized that mental health will increase as age increases (Statistics Canada, 2017). 
Females have consistently shown to have poorer mental health than males in the Canadian population and in various studies (Twenge et al., 2018; Youth Mental Health Canada, n.d.). Therefore, it is hypothesized that there will be a stronger relationship between technology use and mental health for females than males. 
There is research that argues higher socioeconomic status is related to poor mental health (Twenge et al., 2019), and decreased technology use in comparison to lower socioeconomic status individuals (Evan & Kantrowitz, 2002). These findings do not suggest a consistent relationship. However, due to the recency of Twenge et al. (2019) compared to Evan & Kantrowitz (2002) and the similarity between the specific variables in this proposed study and Twenge et al. (2019), it is hypothesized that higher socioeconomic status youth will exhibit a stronger relationship between technology use and poor mental healt

q23.value: This data will be recoded as “System Missing” and will be completely excluded from analyses.

q1.value: Effects of Organizational factors on Safety Outcomes in the Maritime Industry

q2.value: Line Raknes Hjellvik, Sigurd William Hystad, Bjørn Sætrevik

q3.value: Previous research has shown that safety climate is associated with various safety outcomes. As the safety climate is expected to be based on factors that are shared among employees (e.g. the work conditions in the company, or the amount of encouragement from the work-leader), one may expect that employees in the same organizational unit have similar perceptions of safety climate that may have an impact on their safety behaviour. We will therefore examine 1) whether various organizational factors have an impact on the safety climate at various levels in the offshore hydrocarbon production industry, and 2) whether the safety climate has an impact on safety variables at different levels in the offshore hydrocarbon production industry.

q4.value:
We want to investigate what factors it is that predict the safety climate and what outcomes the safety climate may predict. These research questions will be addressed in two separate articles. The first three hypotheses describe expected predictors of safety climate (SC) on different organizational levels, while the final three hypotheses describe predicted outcomes of SC on different levels. 


Research question 1: Predictors of safety climate: 

H1: We expect that the safety climate on the work-shift will be positively associated with...
 H1a: ...frequent contact with the captain 
 H1b: ...the captain's authentic leadership

H2: We expect that the safety climate in the ship-owning company  will be positively associated with ...
 H2a: ...the crew's satisfaction with training and competence
 H2b: ...perceiving work roles as clearly defined

H3: We expect that the safety climate at the client level will be positively associated with ...
 H3a: ...participation in a HSE campaign 
 H3b: ...perceiving the contract with client company to be stable and reliable/predictable

Research question 2: Outcomes of safety climate:

H1: We expect that the safety climate on the work-shift will be….
 H1a: ...negatively associated with subjective risk assessment
 H1b: ...positively associated with safety attitudes
 H1c: ...positively associated with safe actions 

H2: We expect that the safety climate in the ship-owning company will be….
 H2a: ...negatively associated with subjective risk assessment
 H2b: ...positively associated with safety attitudes
 H2c: ...positively associated with safe actions 

H3: We expect that the safety climate in the client company will be…..
 H3a: ...negatively associated with subjective risk assessment
 H3b: ...positively associated with safety attitudes
 H3c: ...positively associated with safe actions

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Four independent cross-sectional surveys (collected in 2013, 2015, 2017 and 2019) will be analysed to investigate predictors and outcomes of safety climate. The four datasets were collected within the same population, and the samples are partially overlapping.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The datasets from 2013, 2015, 2017 and 2019 are ready to be used for the current analysis. Parts of these datasets have been used in past publications, but the associations between the variables specified in the current pre-registration have not been tested.

question.value:
A survey of safety factors was sent to all of the crewmembers working on vessels on hire to a hydrocarbon production company. There were 30-40 surveys distributed to each vessel for all of the employees on both of the vessel's shifts. The employees were encouraged to participate, but participation was voluntary and the participants could withdraw from the study without consequences. The participants completed the survey during their leisure time aboard the vessels. After completing the surveys, participants sent them directly to the researchers in prepaid envelopes. 

The distribution of surveys was organized in such a way that it is not possible to identify any individual crewmember, vessel or ship-owning company. 

Similar data collections were done in 2013, 2015, 2017 and 2019. The variables and items varied somewhat between each year's data collection to adjust for different research interests, HSE foci and feedback from past surveys. The Norwegian Centre for Research Data approved the data handling process.

q13.value: There are 760 valid responses from 49 vessels in the dataset from 2013. There are 411 valid responses from 27 vessels in the dataset from 2015. There are 512 valid responses from 34 vessels in the dataset from 2017. There are 604 valid responses from 47 vessels in the dataset from 2019.

q14.value: All crew members on all vessels chartered by a hydrocarbon production company were invited to participate in the survey. All surveys that were returned to the researchers are included in the analyses.

question.value:
All variables were measured with four pen-and-paper surveys. The items constituting the variables are listed for each variable below. Note that there were some differences in how variables were measured between the four different surveys. An overview of this can be seen in the attached spreadsheet. If not otherwise stated, the response alternatives were divided into “Completely disagree”, “Disagree”, “Neutral”, “Agree” and “Completely agree”. 

“Contact with captain” was measured with one item asking how often the respondents interact or speak with the captain (measured in the same way in all four datasets). The response alternatives were 1) "several times each hour", 2) "several times a day", 3) "several times a week" and 4) "once a week or less".

“Authentic leadership” was measured in 2013 and 2015 with 16 items developed by Walumbwa et al. (2008), Journal of Management. The variable was not measured in 2017 and 2019. The items measure the respondents’ view on the captain’s authentic behaviour, and this includes the four sub-categories: self-awareness, relational transparency, internalized moral perspective and balanced processing. A sample item is “The captain listens carefully to different points of view before coming to conclusions.

“Satisfied with training” was measured with three items in 2013 and 2015, and 12 items in 2017 and 2019. The items are developed in collaboration with industry partners, and some of the items are similar to the ones used in the Brief NORSCI scale developed by Nielsen et al. (2013), Safety Science. The items measure to what extent the respondents think they have the necessary competency, skills and training to perform their job safely. A sample item is: “I have the formal competence that my job position requires”. 

“Role clarity” was measured with seven items in 2015 and 2017. The variable was not measured in 2013 and 2019. The items are from the role conflict and role ambiguity scale developed by House et al. (1983), Journal of Applied Psychology. The items describe statements about expectations and responsibilities, and whether the respondents perceive their job as clearly defined. A sample item is “I know exactly what is expected of me at work”.

“Have participated in HSE activities” was measured with 12 items in 2017 and 2019. The items were not measured in 2013 and 2015. The items measured if the respondents had participated in safety courses and activities aboard their vessels in the past 12 months. A sample item is: “I have participated in a site visit from the ship-owning company with focus on HSE”. 

“Reliability of contract” was measured with eight items in 2017 and 2019. The items were not measured in 2013 and 2015. The items measure to what extent the respondents perceive contractual relationships as safe and whether the relationship between different parties (such as the vessel and installation) are of balanced power. A sample item is: “Pressure from the installations causes us to work in unsafe conditions”. 

“Safety climate” was measured with 44 items at vessel, company and client level. All of the items were included in the surveys in 2013 and 2015. Six of the same items were also included in the 2017 and 2019 surveys. The items are from the safety climate scale developed by Zohar and Luria (2005), Journal of Applied Psychology, which measured safety climate on both organizational and subunit level. The current study measures safety climate on vessel level (16 items), ship-owning company level (16 items) and client-company level (12 items). The 6 items repeated in all four surveys had 2 items on each of the organizational levels. The client and ship-owning company levels correspond to the organizational level (where the client level is the superior level), and the vessel level corresponds to the subunit level. A sample item is: “The captain is strict about working safely when we are tired or stressed”. Safety climate was measured at one level, with 6 items in 2017 and 2019. 

“Safety focus” was measured with 18 items where 6 of the items measured the safety focus at vessel level, 6 of the items measured the safety focus at shipowner level and 6 of the items measured the safety focus at client level. The items measure the leadership and organization's policy is seen as weighting priorities between safety and commercial issues. A sample item is: “The ship-owning company never points out that emphasizing safety can delay the operation”.

“Subjective risk assessment” was measured with items where respondents were asked to estimate the likelihood of being exposed to accidents in the following 12 months. In the 2013 and 2015 dataset, this was measured by seven items asking the participants if they believed they would be exposed to seven different types of accidents, and seven items asking if they believed someone else would be exposed to these accidents. In 2015 there was an additional item asking about the risk for major accidents. In the 2017 and 2019 dataset, three items measured the risk of 1) being exposed to an accident 2) of being exposed to a major accident or 3) of someone else in the work shift being exposed to an accident. 

“Safety attitudes” was measured with three items in 2013, five items in 2015 and eight items in 2017 and 2019. The items measure how the crew member thinks about safety in their day-to-day work. A sample item is: “121 It is acceptable for me to take chances if I am the only person at risk”. Some of the items were taken from Rundmo et al. (1994), Journal of Work Environment and others from Nielsen et al., (2013), Safety Science.

“Safe behaviour” was measured with four items in 2013 and 2015, six items in 2017 and eight items in 2019. The items are developed in collaboration with industry partners to be adapted to the kind of work being performed on the vessels. Some of the items are taken from Rundmo et al. (1994), Journal of Work Environment and Nielsen et al., (2013), Safety Science. The items measure to what extent the participants experience that they work in a safe way. A sample item is: “I stop work if I think it may be dangerous for me or others to continue”.
All of the items in each variable (except for “Contract”, “Contact with captain” and “Have participated in HSE”) will be combined to an average score representing each variable.

We will test the four datasets separately. We will perform regression analyses to test the effects of organizational factors on safety outcomes, and assumptions such as homoscedasticity and multicollinearity will be accounted for. We will use cluster robust variance estimators to account for the hierarchical nature of the data (observations nested in vessels/shifts).

q21.value: We will use two-tailed tests for our directed hypotheses, using p smaller than .05 as inference criteria.

q22.value: No outliers removal or other data exclusion based on response patterns are planned. The captains will be excluded from the analysis as the safety climate and leadership variables include statements where the respondents are to rate the captain’s attitudes and behaviour. Surveys where the professional title (captain or not captain) is excluded will not be included in the analyses.

q24.value: Follow-up analyses may include path analysis for the purpose of testing the model (or specific parts of the model). Follow-up analyses may also include calculation of interrater agreement for the purpose of testing the effects of aggregated climate measures on the outcomes.

attributes.title: Are dogs able to differentiate between true and false beliefs of humans?

q1.value: Are dogs able to differentiate between true and false beliefs of humans?

q2.value: Lucrezia Lonardo, Christoph Völter, Ludwig Huber

q3.value:
Human adults make sense of others’ behaviour by attributing psychological states (e.g. belief, intention, knowledge, desire, etc.) to other agents, an ability that has been termed “Theory of mind” (Premack and Woodruff, 1978). For example, if we see a child stretching out while trying to reach for a high shelf with her hand, we assume that she wants her favourite toy, which is on the shelf. Hence, we constantly engage in the so-called mindreading, explaining others’ behaviour in terms of mental states. 
   Theory of mind is one of the hallmarks of social cognition. Indeed, having a theory of mind enables complex social behaviours such as cooperation, tactical deception, communication and social learning (Heyes 1998; Lurz 2011).
   The possession of a theory of mind can be tested with several different tasks, but a large amount of research attention has been devoted to the so-called false belief task (Wimmer & Perner, 1983). In this paradigm, participants are first familiarised with an agent’s goal (e.g. reaching a desired object). In the crucial false belief condition, the agent’s state of knowledge contrasts with the state of reality (e.g. because the object has been displaced to a different location out of the agent’s view). If participants are capable of attributing a false belief to the agent, they should expect the agent to act according to this false belief and not according to the state of reality.  
   Traditionally, it has been held that children possess a fully developed theory of mind only from the age of 4 years. This limit has been set because it is only from 4 years of age that children can pass verbal false belief tasks, such as the change of location, change of identity and change of content tasks. However recent research has shown that even infants as young as 13 months (Surian et al., 2007) and some non-human animals (Buttelmann et al., 2017; Krupenye et al., 2016), when tested with suitable non-verbal paradigms, can show false beliefs understanding. 

References
1.	Premack, David, and Guy Woodruff. ‘Does the Chimpanzee Have a Theory of Mind?’ Behavioral and Brain Sciences 1, no. 4 (December 1978): 515–26. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0140525X00076512.

2.	Buttelmann, David, Frances Buttelmann, Malinda Carpenter, Josep Call, and Michael Tomasello. ‘Great Apes Distinguish True from False Beliefs in an Interactive Helping Task’. Edited by Juliane Kaminski. PLOS ONE 12, no. 4 (5 April 2017): e0173793. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0173793.

3.	Heyes, C. M. ‘Theory of Mind in Nonhuman Primates’. Behavioral and Brain Sciences 21, no. 1 (February 1998): 101–14. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0140525X98000703.

4.	Krupenye, C., F. Kano, S. Hirata, J. Call, and M. Tomasello. ‘Great Apes Anticipate That Other Individuals Will Act According to False Beliefs’. Science 354, no. 6308 (7 October 2016): 110–14. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aaf8110.

5.	Surian, Luca, and Alessandra Geraci. ‘Where Will the Triangle Look for It? Attributing False Beliefs to a Geometric Shape at 17 Months’. British Journal of Developmental Psychology 30, no. 1 (2012): 30–44. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.2044-835X.2011.02046.x.

6.	‘Mindreading Animals: The Debate over What Animals Know about Other Minds - Robert W. Lurz - Google Books’. q4.value:
With the present study, we aim at investigating whether pet dogs (Canis familiaris) can distinguish between true and false beliefs in an object-choice task. Given the process of domestication and the long history of human-dog cohabitation, dogs represent a particularly interesting model for the study of comparative social cognition. In particular, it has been suggested that, as far as social cognition is concerned, dogs and humans might have undergone a process of convergent evolution throughout phylogeny (Miklósi, 2014). Therefore, we expect to find similarities between the two species in the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying mental state attribution. Previous tests about the dog’s ability to take the perspective of humans in the knower/guesser task using geometrical gaze following have revealed promising results (Catala et al. 2017). This has encouraged us to go a step further and test whether this species is also able to discriminate between a knowledgeable and an ignorant person in the false-belief task. 
    We intend to adapt for dogs a hiding-finding paradigm that has already been used with children and apes (Call and Tomasello, 1999). We hypothesize that dogs will be more inclined to follow the communicator’s hint (reference) to (and hence approach) the empty container in the true belief condition, relative to the false belief condition. On the contrary, when the communicator has a false belief about the location of food, we expect dogs to ignore her reference signals (and hence approach the baited container) more often than in the true belief condition. Regarding the latency to approach the container, we expect that dogs will find the true belief event more puzzling (because the communicator is behaving “irrationally”) and hence we predict that they will have a longer latency to approach the signaled container. 
   During the familiarisation phase, we expect that most dogs will be able to choose the baited container using their memory about the hiding and, in the next phase, following the communicator’s reference signals (i.e. without having witnessed the hiding). 
 During test trials, we expect dogs will remember where food has been hidden last. Therefore, we predict that they will gaze at the baited container longer than at the empty one, prior to the choice. 

References
1.	Miklosi, Adam. Dog Behaviour, Evolution, and Cognition. OUP Oxford, 2014.

2.	Catala, Amélie, Britta Mang, Lisa Wallis, and Ludwig Huber. ‘Dogs Demonstrate Perspective Taking Based on Geometrical Gaze Following in a Guesser–Knower Task’. Animal Cognition 20, no. 4 (July 2017): 581–89. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10071-017-1082-x.

3.	Call, Josep, and Michael Tomasello. ‘A Nonverbal False Belief Task: The Performance of Children and Great Apes’. Child Development 70, no. 2 (1999): 381–95. https://doi.org/10.1111/1467-8624.00028.

We will counterbalance the groups as much as possible for age, sex, breed and first baited box.

question.value:
The experiment will take place in one of the Clever Dog Lab rooms, during a single session of approximately half an hour (including explanations to the owner and breaks for the dog). At the beginning of each trial, the dog, held by its owner, will watch one or two experimenters entering the room and hiding a high-value food bait in one of two opaque containers (box A or box B). Depending on the condition of the experiment, the order of events and the final location of the reward will vary but towards the end of each trial, once the hiding of food is completed, the owner will always be asked to release the dog, who will be free to approach one of the containers and retrieve its content (if any). At the end of each trial, owners will remove the blindfold and recall their dogs to the starting position. Three cameras will record the room from different angles.
      In detail, the experiment will consist of three familiarisation phases and a subsequent test. The familiarisation aims at introducing the dog to the set-up and the experimenters. These are the “hider” (a person who hides food in one of the two containers and displaces the food visibly during displacement trials) and the “communicator” (a person who witnesses the hiding and sometimes the displacement of food and who informs the dog of the location of the bait). 
The first familiarisation phase, called “hider only”, will include two trials. In this phase, only the dog, the owner and the hider will be in the room. The first trial will be a “no displacement”, in which the hider will show to the dog that she has food and she will hide it in box A. Then, she will close the box before leaving the room. In the second trial, dogs will additionally witness a displacement of the food. Immediately after closing box A, the hider will retrieve the food from there and visibly transfer it into box B. Then, after closing the box, she will leave the room. In both cases, owners will be instructed to wait just one second after hearing the closing door and then to release the dog. The dog will be free to approach one of the containers.
If dogs do not move after 10 seconds, owners can give verbal encouragement in the form of releasing commands (e.g. “ok” or “you can go”). If dogs still do not move, we will score the trial as “no choice”. 
We expect that dogs will approach the baited container first. If instead they choose the empty (wrong) container, the hider will go back into the room and remove the food in the other container. 
   The second familiarisation phase, called “communicator only” will also include two trials. This phase serves also as a control condition because it should show that dogs are able to use the communicator’s cue to find food even when they have not witnessed the hiding themselves. The order of displacement and no displacement trials in this condition will be counterbalanced across dogs. Hider and communicator will enter the room while dog and owner will wait outside. From the corridor, dog and owner will have no visual access to the baiting of the containers (the door of the experimental room will be closed). The communicator will start the trial inside the room and therefore she will know in which bucket the food has been hidden. In this phase, the hider will make sure to hide food without making any noise. Then she will leave the room and tell the owner to enter and take the usual seat. When entering the room, the owner will hold the dog so that he/she cannot approach the containers yet. Once the dog will be in the initial position and the owner will be seated and wearing the blindfold again, the communicator will suggest to the dog where to look for food (approach, manipulation of the container, voice and gaze alternation). The communicator will then go back to her neutral starting position and say “ok”. 
   The third and last familiarisation phase, called “hider and communicator” will again involve two trials; the first one will be a no displacement, the second one will be a displacement trial. In this phase, every trial will start with the dog and the owner inside the room. The hider and communicator will enter the room together (with the communicator closely following the hider). The hider will approach the first box to be baited (box A) while the communicator will crouch down facing the dog, in a position equidistant from the two containers, and will (ostensibly) witness the hiding procedure. In the first trial (“no displacement”) the hider will show to the dog that she has food and she will hide it in box A. Then, she will close the box before leaving the room. In the second trial (“displacement”), dogs will additionally witness a displacement of the food. Immediately after closing box A, the hider will retrieve the food from there and visibly transfer it into box B. Then, after closing the box, she will leave the room. In both trials, once the hider has left the room, the communicator will approach the baited container, crouch down close to it, pick it up, alternate gaze three times between it and the dog while saying “look, this is good, this is very good”. Then she will walk back to her starting, neutral, position and she will signal to the owner to release the dog. 
   The test phase will consist of either a true belief (group TRUE) or a false belief trial (group FALSE) (between-subjects design). In this phase, the communicator’s knowledge of the food location will be manipulated. In the false belief condition, the communicator, after witnessing the baiting event, will walk outside of the room, closing the door behind her, pretending not to know what is happening in the experimental room. At this point, the hider will visibly (for the dog) transfer the food from one container to the other, making sure that the dog is watching. Upon returning, the (ignorant) communicator will crouch down on the initial, neutral position and she will wait 2 seconds looking to the floor. Then she will mark the location where she (falsely) believes the food to be (the one which was baited first). In contrast, in the true belief condition, the communicator will leave the room after the first hiding; but while she will be absent (for the same duration as in the false belief condition), nothing will happen in the experimental room, and only upon her returning will the hider translocate the food visibly from one container to the other. Once the hider has left the room closing the door behind her, the communicator will pause again for 2 seconds (looking to the floor) before marking the empty location (the one which was baited first), even though she has (ostensibly) witnessed the transfer of the reward to the other container. 
   Dogs’ first choice, looking times to the containers, and latency to approach the container will be coded offline from video recordings.

q13.value: We aim at a final sample size of 120 pure-bred dogs. This means that we will need to recruit more, depending on how many dogs pass the familiarisation phases.

q14.value:
In order to identify an appropriate sample size, we conducted a simulation. We simulated two groups of dogs, whereby the probability of approaching the baited container was 0.55 in the true belief group and 0.85 in the false belief group. We varied the sample sizes from 24 to 200 (increment: 1) dogs. We then simulated variability between dogs by drawing random numbers from a normal distribution with a mean of zero and a standard deviation being 0.5 times the coefficient for the differences between groups. We conducted 1,000 simulations.
   The power of detecting a significant group effect clearly increased with the number of individuals. The estimated coefficients varied considerably in case of smaller samples sizes of up to about 40 individuals. This was the case for the intercept and the estimated group effect. In case of small samples, a fraction of the simulations obviously led to complete separation (recognizable by large absolute estimates). Based on these simulations, we plan to test about 120 dogs to ensure sufficient power (>80%) for detecting a significant group effect.

q15.value: Data collection will end once we reach our planned sample size of 120 tested pure-bred dogs.

question.value: We will manipulate the communicator’s knowledge state during the test trial. In the false belief condition, the food will be displaced after the communicator has left the experimental room (no knowledge of the change of location). In the true belief condition, the food will be displaced only upon the communicator’s return into the experimental room (knowledge of the food displacement).

We will measure the dogs’ first choice (defined as touch of one of the containers with either nose or front paw) and their latency to touch the chosen container from the moment of being released. 
Additionally, we will code the looking durations of each dog to the baited and to the empty container during the two seconds in which the communicator is crouched down on the neutral position and looking to the floor. We will stop coding looking durations immediately before the communicator´s first movement.

As dependent variables, we are going to analyse the latency to approach the container and the first choice in the test trial. To analyse the effect of the test condition (true/false belief) on the probability to choose the baited container (i.e. to ignore the communicator’s cues), we will fit a Generalized Linear Mixed Model with binomial error structure and logit link function McCullagh and Nelder (1989).
   We will include in the model the test condition as key test predictor. Age, sex and first baited box (A or B) will be included as control predictors (fixed effects), while dog breed will be included as random effect, to control for variance among breeds. We will also include all possible random slope components (without the correlations). Prior to fitting the model, we will z-transform age to make the interpretation of the estimates more meaningful. In order to rule out collinearity issues, we will determine Variance Inflation Factors using the function vif (R package car, R Core Team, 2019). We will estimate model stability by removing the breeds one at a time from the data and comparing the estimates derived for models fitted to these subsets with those obtained for the full data set. 

Generalized linear mixed model: first choice ~ Condition + z.Age + Sex + First baited box + (1 + Condition + z.Age + Sex + First baited box ||breed ID), family =binomial
If, still, the model does not converge, we will follow the steps reported here: https://rpubs.com/bbolker/lme4trouble1
If these procedures do not fix convergence issues, then we will: 
1.	Remove random slopes (in the following order): First baited box, sex, age
2.	Remove the control variable First baited box

   With regards to the latency, we will fit a Generalized Linear Model with gamma error structure. As above, we will include in the model the test condition as key test predictor.  Age, sex and first baited box (A or B) will be included as control predictors (fixed effects), while dog breed will be included as random effect. 

Generalized linear mixed model: latency to approach ~ Condition + z.Age + Sex + First baited box + (1 + Condition + z.Age + Sex + First baited box ||breed ID), family =gamma (link="log")
If the model does not converge, we will follow the steps reported here: https://rpubs.com/bbolker/lme4trouble1
If these procedures do not fix convergence issues, then we will: 
1.	Remove random slopes (in the following order): First baited box, sex, age
2.	Remove the control variable First baited box

To verify if dogs remember the correct location of food after the displacement, we are going to analyse dogs´ looking behaviours. 
 We will fit a Generalized Linear Model with beta error structure. The response variable will be the proportion of looking times to the baited container relative to the looking times to both containers. As above, we will include in the model the test condition as test predictor.  Age, sex and first baited box (A or B) will be included as control predictors (fixed effects), while dog breed will be included as random effect.
Generalized linear mixed model: proportion of looking time to the baited container ~ Condition + z.Age + Sex + First baited box + (1 + Condition + z.Age + Sex + First baited box ||breed ID), family=beta_family
Convergence issues will be treated as above. 
In this analysis, we are also interested in deviations from the hypothetical chance level of 0.5. Therefore, we will re-fit the model with all predictor variables centred and examine whether the intercept deviates significantly from the chance level.

Finally, as a manipulation check, we are interested in assessing whether dogs can use the communicator´s signal to find food when they have not witnessed the hiding themselves (and without any previous training or knowledge of the communicator). Therefore, we will code each dog´s choice on the first trial of the second familiarisation (“hider only”) phase and we will run a binomial test with chance level equal to 0.5, including all the dogs that were tested in the first trial of the second familiarisation phase (even those that were excluded before the final test).

q20.value:
We will z-transform age to a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.
We will center all random slope components.

q21.value:
P-values smaller than .05 will be used as criterion to make inferences about fixed effects.

GLMM: We will only focus on the significance of the test predictor (p smaller than .05) except for the looking time model with centered predictor variables in which we analyze deviations from the chance level. Likelihood ratio tests (R function drop1 with argument 'test' set to "Chisq") with p smaller than .05 will be used as criterion to make inferences about fixed effects.

q22.value: To make sure that dogs are attentive and motivated enough, we are only going to test dogs that meet a learning criterion for each of the three familiarisation phases. For each phase, dogs will witness a minimum of two trials, one with food displacement and one without. If they are correct in both trials, they will move to the next phase; otherwise, both trials will be repeated. Hence, to be tested, dogs must approach the baited containers (A and B) in two consecutive trials within 4 trials per phase. This means that a maximum of 12 familiarisation trials is possible.

registration_responses.q1: Are dogs able to differentiate between true and false beliefs of humans?
registration_responses.q2: Lucrezia Lonardo, Christoph Völter, Ludwig Huber
registration_responses.q3:
Human adults make sense of others’ behaviour by attributing psychological states (e.g. belief, intention, knowledge, desire, etc.) to other agents, an ability that has been termed “Theory of mind” (Premack and Woodruff, 1978). For example, if we see a child stretching out while trying to reach for a high shelf with her hand, we assume that she wants her favourite toy, which is on the shelf. Hence, we constantly engage in the so-called mindreading, explaining others’ behaviour in terms of mental states. 
   Theory of mind is one of the hallmarks of social cognition. Indeed, having a theory of mind enables complex social behaviours such as cooperation, tactical deception, communication and social learning (Heyes 1998; Lurz 2011).
   The possession of a theory of mind can be tested with several different tasks, but a large amount of research attention has been devoted to the so-called false belief task (Wimmer & Perner, 1983). In this paradigm, participants are first familiarised with an agent’s goal (e.g. reaching a desired object). In the crucial false belief condition, the agent’s state of knowledge contrasts with the state of reality (e.g. because the object has been displaced to a different location out of the agent’s view). If participants are capable of attributing a false belief to the agent, they should expect the agent to act according to this false belief and not according to the state of reality.  
   Traditionally, it has been held that children possess a fully developed theory of mind only from the age of 4 years. This limit has been set because it is only from 4 years of age that children can pass verbal false belief tasks, such as the change of location, change of identity and change of content tasks. However recent research has shown that even infants as young as 13 months (Surian et al., 2007) and some non-human animals (Buttelmann et al., 2017; Krupenye et al., 2016), when tested with suitable non-verbal paradigms, can show false beliefs understanding. 

References
1.	Premack, David, and Guy Woodruff. ‘Does the Chimpanzee Have a Theory of Mind?’ Behavioral and Brain Sciences 1, no. 4 (December 1978): 515–26. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0140525X00076512.

2.	Buttelmann, David, Frances Buttelmann, Malinda Carpenter, Josep Call, and Michael Tomasello. ‘Great Apes Distinguish True from False Beliefs in an Interactive Helping Task’. Edited by Juliane Kaminski. PLOS ONE 12, no. 4 (5 April 2017): e0173793. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0173793.

3.	Heyes, C. M. ‘Theory of Mind in Nonhuman Primates’. Behavioral and Brain Sciences 21, no. 1 (February 1998): 101–14. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0140525X98000703.

4.	Krupenye, C., F. Kano, S. Hirata, J. Call, and M. Tomasello. ‘Great Apes Anticipate That Other Individuals Will Act According to False Beliefs’. Science 354, no. 6308 (7 October 2016): 110–14. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aaf8110.

5.	Surian, Luca, and Alessandra Geraci. ‘Where Will the Triangle Look for It? Attributing False Beliefs to a Geometric Shape at 17 Months’. British Journal of Developmental Psychology 30, no. 1 (2012): 30–44. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.2044-835X.2011.02046.x.

6.	‘Mindreading Animals: The Debate over What Animals Know about Other Minds - Robert W. Lurz - Google Books’. Accessed 21 February 2020. https://books.google.at/books?hl=en&lr=&id=7NHxCwAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PP1&dq=lurz+2011&ots=DlcbRKF5q7&sig=uM0ilViCSCbAO8zwaDuI8SVoOy0&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=lurz%202011&f=false.

7.	Wimmer, Heinz, and Josef Perner. ‘Beliefs about Beliefs: Representation and Constraining Function of Wrong Beliefs in Young Children’s Understanding of Deception’. Cognition 13, no. 1 (1 January 1983): 103–28. https://doi.org/10.1016/0010-0277(83)90004-5.

The hider will approach the first box to be baited (box A) while the communicator will crouch down facing the dog, in a position equidistant from the two containers, and will (ostensibly) witness the hiding procedure. In the first trial (“no displacement”) the hider will show to the dog that she has food and she will hide it in box A. Then, she will close the box before leaving the room. In the second trial (“displacement”), dogs will additionally witness a displacement of the food. Immediately after closing box A, the hider will retrieve the food from there and visibly transfer it into box B. Then, after closing the box, she will leave the room. In both trials, once the hider has left the room, the communicator will approach the baited container, crouch down close to it, pick it up, alternate gaze three times between it and the dog while saying “look, this is good, this is very good”. Then she will walk back to her starting, neutral, position and she will signal to the owner to release the dog. 
   The test phase will consist of either a true belief (group TRUE) or a false belief trial (group FALSE) (between-subjects design). In this phase, the communicator’s knowledge of the food location will be manipulated. In the false belief condition, the communicator, after witnessing the baiting event, will walk outside of the room, closing the door behind her, pretending not to know what is happening in the experimental room. At this point, the hider will visibly (for the dog) transfer the food from one container to the other, making sure that the dog is watching. Upon returning, the (ignorant) communicator will crouch down on the initial, neutral position and she will wait 2 seconds looking to the floor. Then she will mark the location where she (falsely) believes the food to be (the one which was baited first). In contrast, in the true belief condition, the communicator will leave the room after the first hiding; but while she will be absent (for the same duration as in the false belief condition), nothing will happen in the experimental room, and only upon her returning will the hider translocate the food visibly from one container to the other. Once the hider has left the room closing the door behind her, the communicator will pause again for 2 seconds (looking to the floor) before marking the empty location (the one which was baited first), even though she has (ostensibly) witnessed the transfer of the reward to the other container. 
   Dogs’ first choice, looking times to the containers, and latency to approach the container will be coded offline from video recordings.
registration_responses.q16.question: We will manipulate the communicator’s knowledge state during the test trial. In the false belief condition, the food will be displaced after the communicator has left the experimental room (no knowledge of the change of location). In the true belief condition, the food will be displaced only upon the communicator’s return into the experimental room (knowledge of the food displacement).
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will measure the dogs’ first choice (defined as touch of one of the containers with either nose or front paw) and their latency to touch the chosen container from the moment of being released. 
Additionally, we will code the looking durations of each dog to the baited and to the empty container during the two seconds in which the communicator is crouched down on the neutral position and looking to the floor. We will stop coding looking durations immediately before the communicator´s first movement.
registration_responses.q19.question:
As dependent variables, we are going to analyse the latency to approach the container and the first choice in the test trial. To analyse the effect of the test condition (true/false belief) on the probability to choose the baited container (i.e. to ignore the communicator’s cues), we will fit a Generalized Linear Mixed Model with binomial error structure and logit link function McCullagh and Nelder (1989).
   We will include in the model the test condition as key test predictor. Age, sex and first baited box (A or B) will be included as control predictors (fixed effects), while dog breed will be included as random effect, to control for variance among breeds. We will also include all possible random slope components (without the correlations). Prior to fitting the model, we will z-transform age to make the interpretation of the estimates more meaningful. In order to rule out collinearity issues, we will determine Variance Inflation Factors using the function vif (R package car, R Core Team, 2019). We will estimate model stability by removing the breeds one at a time from the data and comparing the estimates derived for models fitted to these subsets with those obtained for the full data set. 

Generalized linear mixed model: first choice ~ Condition + z.Age + Sex + First baited box + (1 + Condition + z.Age + Sex + First baited box ||breed ID), family =binomial
If, still, the model does not converge, we will follow the steps reported here: https://rpubs.com/bbolker/lme4trouble1
If these procedures do not fix convergence issues, then we will: 
1.	Remove random slopes (in the following order): First baited box, sex, age
2.	Remove the control variable First baited box

   With regards to the latency, we will fit a Generalized Linear Model with gamma error structure. As above, we will include in the model the test condition as key test predictor.  Age, sex and first baited box (A or B) will be included as control predictors (fixed effects), while dog breed will be included as random effect. 

Generalized linear mixed model: latency to approach ~ Condition + z.Age + Sex + First baited box + (1 + Condition + z.Age + Sex + First baited box ||breed ID), family =gamma (link="log")
If the model does not converge, we will follow the steps reported here: https://rpubs.com/bbolker/lme4trouble1
If these procedures do not fix convergence issues, then we will: 
1.	Remove random slopes (in the following order): First baited box, sex, age
2.	Remove the control variable First baited box

To verify if dogs remember the correct location of food after the displacement, we are going to analyse dogs´ looking behaviours. 
 We will fit a Generalized Linear Model with beta error structure. The response variable will be the proportion of looking times to the baited container relative to the looking times to both containers. As above, we will include in the model the test condition as test predictor.  Age, sex and first baited box (A or B) will be included as control predictors (fixed effects), while dog breed will be included as random effect.
Generalized linear mixed model: proportion of looking time to the baited container ~ Condition + z.Age + Sex + First baited box + (1 + Condition + z.Age + Sex + First baited box ||breed ID), family=beta_family
Convergence issues will be treated as above. 
In this analysis, we are also interested in deviations from the hypothetical chance level of 0.5. Therefore, we will re-fit the model with all predictor variables centred and examine whether the intercept deviates significantly from the chance level.

Finally, as a manipulation check, we are interested in assessing whether dogs can use the communicator´s signal to find food when they have not witnessed the hiding themselves (and without any previous training or knowledge of the communicator). Therefore, we will code each dog´s choice on the first trial of the second familiarisation (“hider only”) phase and we will run a binomial test with chance level equal to 0.5, including all the dogs that were tested in the first trial of the second familiarisation phase (even those that were excluded before the final test).

attributes.title: The Factor Structure of Aggression Scales

q2.value: David Chester, Courtland Hyatt, Josh Miller, Michael L. Crowe

q3.value:
Analyses on Study 2 produced a reduced set of items that pared the original item-set of 733 items down to 372 by removing items that: 
-were derived from a copyrighted scale
-had greater than 90.00% '1 - Strongly Disagree' responses (no items had greater than 90% '7 - Strongly Agree' responses)
-exhibited inter-item correlations at r = .65 or higher

The goal of Study 3 was to administer this reduced item-set to a new sample of undergraduates alongside several validity measures:
-IPIP-NEO-60
-Self-Report Altruism Scale
-UPPSP Impulsivity Scale

q4.value:
This is largely an exploratory study that will use the 'bass-ackwards' analytic approach to model the factor structure of aggression self-report data as a function of an increasing number of latent factors. We expect that several important dimensions of aggression will manifest early in this process, in the following order (from earlier in the analytic process to later):
-physical versus verbal aggression
-retaliatory versus unprovoked aggression
-impulsive versus premeditated aggression
-intimate-partner versus non-intimate-partner aggression
-alcohol-related versus non-alcohol-related aggression

The model that will best fit the data is unknown, though the latent factors are expected to be positively correlated.

Trait agreeableness and altruism will be negatively associated with each factor, as criterion validity checks. 

Impulsive/reactive aggression factors will be:
-positively associated with negative and positive urgency.
-negatively associated with conscientiousness.
-positively associated with the 'Anger' sub-subscale of the Neuroticism facet.

Premeditated/proactive aggression factors will be: 
-negatively associated with a (lack of) premeditation and (lack of) perseverance.
-positively associated with conscientiousness.

Verbal aggression factors will be positively associated with extraversion.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This project is a correlational, cross-sectional, between-participants study, that will employ the Bass-Ackwards statistical approach. This approach conducts factor analyses at increasing levels of specificity, while simultaneously modeling the relations between each latent factor. Further, aggression self-report data will be collected in a planned missingness design, such that participants will complete a random sample of 200 self-report items from a larger list of 372 items.

Cross-sectional correlations will also be used to characterize the nomological network related to each aggression factor that is derived from the Bass-Ackwards analyses.

q9.value: From a battery of 372 self-report aggression items, participants will complete a randomly-selected subset of 200 items. Qualtrics' advanced randomization tool with 'present items evenly' selected will be used to conduct such randomization.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Study 3 is currently running and the data was downloaded once 49 participants had completed the study to ensure accurate recording of participant responses and whether the randomization procedure was working. No hypotheses were tested and no inferential statistics were conducted during this data check.

question.value: Participants will complete this online survey at a date/time of their choosing, and they will receive 1 research credit-hour for their participation. Participants will be recruited from an online participant pool that prohibits students who are under the age of 18.

q13.value: 910 participants will be collected for this study.

q15.value: Data collection will cease once data from 910 participants have been acquired.

question.value: Participants will complete a randomized subset of 200 aggression self-report items from a larger body of 372 items.

We will measure the following constructs:
1. Demographics: age, sex at birth, current gender identity, racial identity, household income

2. The 372 item aggression battery created from Study 2

3. Trait agreeableness, conscientiousness, extraversion, neuroticism, and openness to experience via the IPIP-NEO-60 questionnaire.

4. Altruistic behavior via the 20-item Self-Report Altruism Scale.

5. Negative urgency, lack of perseverance, lack of premeditation, sensation-seeking, and positive urgency via the UPPS+P Impulsivity Scale.

-aggression subscales will be created from the factors identified in the bass-ackwards analyses by averaging together the appropriate items (after reverse-scoring appropriate items)
-all other measures will be computed by averaging together all responses (after reverse-scoring appropriate items)

-----------Bass-Ackwards Analyses-----------
Step 1. Data from the self-reported aggression items will be examined via descriptive statistics. Any item with 90% or more of the participant sample indicating a '1 - Strongly Disagree' response will be eliminated from the dataset.

Step 2. Remaining items will be correlated with each other and any item-pair with r greater than .65 will have one item removed from the dataset in an iterative fashion, removing the item with the most .65 correlations until no such redundantly correlated items exist.

Step 3. Remaining items will then be entered into an unrotated principal axis factor analysis with promax rotation. In the first iteration of this analysis, a single, unrotated factor will be extracted. Any item with a factor loading below the absolute value of 0.30 onto the first extracted component will be removed from the dataset.

Step 4. This final item pool will then be entered into a series of principal axis factor analyses with promax rotation. In the first iteration of this analysis, a single, unrotated factor will be extracted. Each subsequent iteration of this analysis will extract an additional, rotated factor until the investigator team determines that one of the factors is either so specific that it is not conceptually meaningful or interpretable. We will retain each item's factor loadings at each iteration of these factor analyses, as well as each factor's eigenvalues, and each factor solutions' model fit indices (chi-square, Comparative Fit Index, Tucker-Lewis Index, Root Mean Square Error of Approximation). 

Step 5. Item-level factor loadings from each factor solution will be correlated with one another to examine underlying relations across solutions. Factor loadings for each item must meet or exceed an absolute value of .35 for that item to be retained as part of the given factor.

---Validity Checks---
As a criterion validity check, we will conduct bivariate correlations between each factor subscale that is created from the bass-ackwards analyses and its corresponding validity scales.

q20.value: No transformations will be applied to the data.

q21.value: For the criterion validity checks, bivariate associations with a positive r value, a p-value less than.05, and a 95% confidence interval around the r value that does not include 0, will be required for inferential support.

q22.value:
Participants who have not had a previous romantic partner will be excluded from completing any items regarding romantic partner aggression.

Participants who have not previously consumed alcohol will be excluded from completing any items regarding alcohol-related aggression.

q24.value: An exploratory factor analysis will be conducted and a Horn's parallel analysis will be used to identify the number of factors that are suggested quantitatively. This solution will be compared to the theoretically-derived solution.

attributes.title: How Refugees Shape National Boundaries by Challenging Them

q1.value: How Refugees Shape National Boundaries by Challenging Them

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: How do refugees impact their local, host environments? This dissertation project theorizes that the exogenous shock of forced migration may have unforeseen consequences for nationalism and nation-building in the host country. Refugees may strengthen nearby native citizens' national solidarity due to threat from outsiders and fears of ethnic conflict diffusion. Additionally, the influx of international and government aid into refugee camps often stands in contrast to the lack of local public goods in nearby host communities. Refugees, by challenging national borders and highlighting inequalities in welfare, can inadvertently spur natives to rally around their national identity and become more active citizens, contributing to provide and demanding for better public goods provision. To test this theory, this research design details plans for a survey with two experimental components in Western Tanzania, comparing attitudes and behaviors of citizen respondents living near versus far from refugees.

q16.value: 1. A refugee influx signals weak physical borders, compelling nearby citizens to support symbolic national boundaries of exclusion such as restrictive immigration laws. 2. (a) The presence of refugees spur nearby host citizens to rally around their national identity. (b) This increased nationalism, while exclusionary, may have downstream effects on active citizenship and nation-building by motivating citizens to contribute more and make demands for public goods. 3. Both practical-rational and social identity concerns can explain anti-refugee attitudes: namely, (a) while unfounded, perceptions that refugees bring insecurity (e.g. weapons, crime, violence and disease) as well as the influx of international and government aid into refugee camps to which citizens do not have access and (b) differences in social identity (measured through common language) and religion.

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested through a survey that gathers both observational and experimental data from a sample size of 2000 respondents from across the six districts in Kigoma in the western region of Tanzania bordering Burundi and the DR Congo. The main analyses will compare attitudes and behaviors of 1) citizen respondents living nearer versus farther from the main refugee camp Nyarugusu and 2) respondents randomly primed in the survey with factual information on refugees in their country. The main outcomes of interest are respondents' attachment to national identity relative to other identities. It also includes behavioral components which measures respondents' i) willingness to contribute to public goods and ii) willingness to deliver a message to their local government. Lastly, the survey will examine the types of migrant threat that may explain anti-refugee attitudes in local citizens.

attributes.title: The Evolution of Risk and Social Preferences: Evidence from Two Natural Experiments in Sierra Leone

q1.value: The Evolution of Risk and Social Preferences: Evidence from Two Natural Experiments in Sierra Leone

q2.value: Imran Rasul | Markus Goldstein | Niklas Buehren | Andrea Smurra

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Over the past century, the history of many low- and middle-income countries has been shaped by armed conflict. Despite the tragic impact such episodes have on the lives of victims, and the destruction of human and physical capital, macro-orientated evidence suggests that post-war periods are usually characterized by rapid economic recovery [Miguel and Roland 2006, Cerra and Saxena 2009]. However, legacies of conflict extend beyond aggregate output, and recent contributions have documented how exposure to civil war can foster pro-social behavior [Bauer et al. 2016]. To the extent that such changes in norms and preferences foster trust, cooperation and public goods provision, this could then in turn explain patterns of post-war economic recovery [Knack and Keefer 1997]. Yet the direction of such impacts is unclear: exposure to conflict might foster empathy and trust [Hartman and Morse, 2018], but can also lead to parochial altruism at the expense of less across-group cooperation [Bowles, 2008]. Similarly, risk preferences could adjust either way in response to conflict, and so lead to under saving or excess precautionary saving, or profitable investment opportunities not being undertaken. Hence understanding the microeconomic links between conflict, and disruptive crises more generally, and preference formation has important implications for understanding potential mediators driving macroeconomic outcomes in post-recovery periods, as well as aiding the design of social reconciliation interventions, and the allocation of external aid.

q16.value: 1)What is the impact of exposure to aggregate shocks and traumas, such as armed conflict or disease epidemics, on preference formation such as risk and social preferences? 2)Does exposure to trauma from armed conflict affect survivors’ resilience to subsequent traumas? 3)Does age of exposure matter, and how persistent are any effects on preference formation?

q17.value: Our study addresses the research questions above using a primary collected panel data set for this purpose, from adolescent girls aged 12-24, residing in Sierra Leone from 2014 onwards. We will examine risk attitudes, social preferences and trust for a large sample of respondents that were born during the 1991-2001 Civil War and exposed to varying degrees of violence. In addition, this sample was interviewed right before and shortly after the 2014 Ebola outbreak. The definition of each outcome variable, as well as the methodology employed to measure exposure to conflict and to Ebola-related socio-economic hardship are detailed in the attached PAP.

registration_responses.q15: Over the past century, the history of many low- and middle-income countries has been shaped by armed conflict. Despite the tragic impact such episodes have on the lives of victims, and the destruction of human and physical capital, macro-orientated evidence suggests that post-war periods are usually characterized by rapid economic recovery [Miguel and Roland 2006, Cerra and Saxena 2009]. However, legacies of conflict extend beyond aggregate output, and recent contributions have documented how exposure to civil war can foster pro-social behavior [Bauer et al. 2016]. To the extent that such changes in norms and preferences foster trust, cooperation and public goods provision, this could then in turn explain patterns of post-war economic recovery [Knack and Keefer 1997]. Yet the direction of such impacts is unclear: exposure to conflict might foster empathy and trust [Hartman and Morse, 2018], but can also lead to parochial altruism at the expense of less across-group cooperation [Bowles, 2008]. Similarly, risk preferences could adjust either way in response to conflict, and so lead to under saving or excess precautionary saving, or profitable investment opportunities not being undertaken. Hence understanding the microeconomic links between conflict, and disruptive crises more generally, and preference formation has important implications for understanding potential mediators driving macroeconomic outcomes in post-recovery periods, as well as aiding the design of social reconciliation interventions, and the allocation of external aid.

attributes.title: Activity Diversity, Hippocampal Volume, and Cognitive Functioning
attributes.description: The hippocampus, which is involved in learning and memory, is one of the few structures in the brain that demonstrates neurogenesis across the lifespan (Eriksson et al., 1998; Spalding et al., 2013). This neurogenesis is hypothesized to support the ability to flexibly navigate novel situations and environments (Kempermann, 2008). In humans, the extent of navigational abilities has been related to hippocampal volume (Maguire et al., 2000; Maguire, Woollett, & Spiers, 2006), and in genetically identical mice greater hippocampal neurogenesis was related to a greater range of territory explored independent of total amount of movement (termed “roaming entropy”; Freund et al., 2013). Hippocampal volume, then, may be a marker of exposure to and engagement with novel events and environments. Activity diversity, or the range and evenness of participation in daily activities, has previously been associated with better executive functioning in humans (Lee, Charles, & Almeida, in press), which is characterized by the ability to adapt cognitively to different situations, but has not yet been examined in relation to hippocampal structure. The present research will examine how hippocampal volume relates to activity diversity, above and beyond total activity time, in two samples of US adults across the span of 8 days. Furthermore, the relationship between hippocampal volume, activity diversity, and cognitive functioning will be explored.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration
